This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

According to [GiveWell](https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/wageningen-university-sierra-leone-rct-2024):

>In May 2024, GiveWell made a $676,857 grant to Wageningen University to include additional components to a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of door-to-door health service delivery in remote communities in Sierra Leone. Non-GiveWell funding was already covering one round of service delivery and surveys, including the provision of routine childhood and HPV vaccines, vitamin A supplements, and deworming pills. This grant will add chlorine, for disinfecting drinking water, and oral rehydration solution (ORS) and zinc, for treating dehydration due to diarrhea, to the bundle of health services that will be delivered, and will support a second round of service delivery and surveys 3 months after the initial round.

GiveWell estimates that reduction in diarrhea deaths via chlorine and ORS/zinc could raise the cost-effectiveness estimate of health commodities distribution programs like this one, if usage is high.

The study's design is as follows:

>The study will be a cluster-randomized RCT in which the treatment communities receive household-to-household visits from health teams offering routine childhood and HPV vaccines to those who have not received all of the vaccines in the vaccination schedule. Households with children under the age of 5 will also be offered VAS, deworming pills, chlorine to treat drinking water, and ORS/zinc to treat future diarrhea episodes. **The effect of a six-month programme of intradialytic cycling on survival and hospitalisations in people requiring haemodialysis: 5-year follow-up of the CYCLE-HD randomised controlled trial**
The 5‑year follow‑up of the CYCLE‑HD randomised controlled trial examined whether a six‑month intradialytic cycling (IDC) programme affects long‑term clinical outcomes in haemodialysis patients. The analysis found no significant difference between the IDC and control groups for all‑cause mortality, cardiovascular events (a composite of cardiovascular deaths and hospitalisations), all‑cause hospitalisations or hospital length of stay. Age was associated with a 3.2% increased risk of cardiovascular events per additional year, and diabetes with an 89% increased risk. The cohort had a 5‑year mortality of 55%, with 18% of deaths attributable to cardiovascular causes.

The authors compared their results with other exercise trials. The EXCITE trial, which used a six‑month home walking programme, reported a 29% reduction in the composite outcome of hospitalisation and mortality (HR 0.71, 95% CI 0.50–1.00, p = 0.06) at 36 months post‑trial. The DIATT trial, a 12‑month intradialytic exercise programme, showed significant reductions in hospitalisations (p = 0.024) and days in hospital (p = 0.036). Another study reported a 12‑month mortality HR of 0.17 (95% CI 0.04–0.8, p = 0.02) after a six‑month IDC programme, though the confidence interval was wide.

A post‑hoc sample‑size calculation suggested that 955 participants would be required to detect a statistically significant 9% reduction in hospitalisations. Limitations include the small sample size, post‑hoc design, lack of sustained exercise after the initial six months, and potential missing hospitalisation data outside the University Hospitals of Leicester.

**Cholera remains public health challenge - University Dons - Businessday NG**
A media roundtable organised by Cochrane Nigeria and the Institute of Tropical Diseases Research and Prevention in Calabar highlighted that cholera remains a major public health threat. Pediatric gastroenterologist Ekong Udoh noted that the disease causes about 2.9 million cases and 95,000 deaths worldwide each year, with Africa accounting for over 90 % of the burden. In Nigeria, 4,809 suspected cases and 156 deaths were reported in 2024, compared with 260 deaths in northern Nigeria in 2009. Udoh explained that 75 % of infected people are asymptomatic yet shed bacteria for up to two weeks, and that 20 % of symptomatic patients develop severe dehydration; untreated cholera can kill 30–50 % of cases. He stressed that prompt fluid replacement with oral rehydration solution (ORS) is life‑saving, but access to care remains limited in remote areas. Antibiotic resistance is emerging, with strains resistant to tetracycline and doxycycline already documented. Prevention, he argued, is cheaper and more effective: boiling water, handwashing, and proper food handling can cut diarrhoea by 26–62 %. Oral cholera vaccines (OCVs) such as Shanchol and Euvichol provide up to 65 % protection for five years, while a single dose of Shanchol can reduce cases by 40 % at six months. Dr. Ekpereonne Esu added that OCVs are WHO‑prequalified and can be given to individuals from one year of age, including pregnant women and those with HIV. He cited trials showing a two‑dose Dukoral regimen reduced cases by 76 % at two years, and Shanchol reduced severe disease by 63 %. Esu warned that vaccines alone cannot end cholera; they must be coupled with improved water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) infrastructure. He called for political will, community engagement and sustained investment to accelerate prevention and control.
